awd_abstract_narration:
Catalysis is a process in which a small amount of a substance (a catalyst) accelerates the rate of desirable chemical reactions. Catalysis plays a vital role in many industrial applications. Manufacturing valuable products such as pharmaceuticals, plastics, agrochemicals, and clean fuels often requires properly designed catalysts. Traditional catalysts are highly effective in promoting a wide range of chemical reactions. However, it remains a daunting task to make catalysts that emulate the remarkable performance of enzymes, which are Nature's catalysts. The challenge arises largely from the difficulty of constructing molecules that resemble the complexity of enzymes. In this project, Dr. Zhenqiang Wang of the University of South Dakota is applying several biology-inspired principles to synthesize new classes of molecules that mimic enzymes. This research is integrated with educational outreach programs targeting Native American students to promote STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) education. These programs are engaging local tribal college students through tribal student-faculty research teams hosted in Dr. Wang's laboratory and through chemistry workshops at regional tribal colleges. The outreach also includes onsite hosting of students from local primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs) and "at-home" support for student-faculty research teams at their home institutions.

In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis program of the Chemistry Division, the team led by Dr. Wang at the University of South Dakota is utilizing a unique class of synthetic receptors, known as metal-organic supercontainers (MOSCs), to investigate new concepts of catalysis. The MOSC-based supramolecular catalysts are structurally unique in that they are constructed from container-molecule precursors (i.e., sulfonylcalixarenes) and feature multiple nano-cavities that serve as substrate binding sites. The MOSC catalysts also feature functionally versatile metal-bound H2O species, which may promote hydrogen-bond, Bronsted-acid, Bronsted-base, and cascade catalysis. Two key strategies, namely, multifunctional nano-cavities and electrostatic regulation, are used to promote the catalytic efficacy, enhance reaction selectivity, and regulate supramolecular reactivity. The unique structural characteristics of the MOSCs, including their compositional versatility, structural modularity, and multi-pore architecture, distinguish them from other synthetic receptor molecules and provide unprecedented opportunities for functionalizing catalytic active sites and engineering supramolecular reactivity. The strategy to modulate supramolecular catalysis using ionic species as electrostatic regulators, which are catalytically inert on their own, is conceptually distinct from conventional methods that rely on encapsulating catalytically active species. The concept of electrostatic regulation is not yet fully recognized by chemists, but has the potential to not only significantly expand the scope of accessible reactions, but fundamentally transform how supramolecular catalysis can be designed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Catalysis is a process in which a small amount of a substance (a catalyst) accelerates the rate of desirable chemical reactions. Catalysis plays a vital role in many industrial applications. Manufacturing valuable products such as pharmaceuticals, plastics, agrochemicals, and clean fuels often requires properly designed catalysts. Traditional catalysts were highly effective in promoting a wide range of chemical reactions. However, it remained a daunting task to make catalysts that emulated the remarkable performance of enzymes, which are Nature's catalysts. The challenge arose largely from the difficulty of constructing catalyst structures that resembled the complexity of enzymes.

The overarching goal of this project was to utilize a new class of synthetic receptors, known as metal-organic supercontainers (MOSCs), to investigate new concepts of catalysis and emulate enzymatic catalysis. The unique structural characteristics of the MOSCs included their compositional versatility, structural modularity, and multi-pore architecture, which distinguished them from other types of catalysts. We established two key strategies of catalysis, namely, supramolecular catalysis via multifunctional nano-cavities and catalytic regulation via electrostatic interactions. These strategies provided new opportunities to promote catalytic efficacy, enhance reaction selectivity, and regulate supramolecular reactivity.

Through this project, we showed that MOSC catalysts featuring novel cavity structures can be custom-designed and that cavity-dependent catalytic properties can be demonstrated through chemically fine-tuning the multi-functional nano-environment of the MOSCs. Interesting size-, shape-, regio-, and chemo-selectivity can be achieved through functionalization (e.g., fluorination) of MOSC cavity, controlling the cavity size, and/or modulating the Lewis acidity or basicity of the MOSCs. We demonstrated that the endo cavity of the MOSC catalysts contained chemically versatile metal-bound μ4-H2O species, which can be made catalytically active for hydrogen-bond, Brønsted-acid, or Brønsted-base catalysis, depending on the type of reactions and substrates used. We established a conceptually unique and novel strategy to modulate supramolecular catalysis using ionic species as electrostatic regulators, which were catalytically inert on their own. We examined both cationic and anionic electrostatic regulators and found that they can inhibit some reactions but promote others through mediation by the MOSC cavities.

We demonstrated that “structural defects” can be rationally installed in the MOSC structure to generate partially open endo cavity and labile open metal sites, which were shown to be beneficial for encapsulating/activating substrates and enabling selective oxidation of primary alcohols to carboxylic acids. We found that the otherwise hydrophobic MOSCs can be functionalized with sulfonato (-SO3-) groups to impart the MOSCs with good water-solubility. The dichotomy of an overall water-solubility and an isolated hydrophobic nano-cavity proved uniquely suited for a new form of heterogeneous catalysis at liquid-liquid interface, which points to exciting new directions of supramolecular catalysis. Finally, we developed a library of new MOSCs that retained similar multi-pore supercontainer topologies but featured distinct chemical and structural characteristics, such as a diverse range of metal ions, organic precursors, tunable pores, positive or negative charges, open metal sites, structural flexibility, etc., providing new opportunities for future supramolecular catalytic studies.

Thus, this grant provided the PI with the support to develop a new class of supramolecular catalysts that featured novel multi-cavity structure and unique catalytic characteristics. The grant contributed directly or indirectly to eight peer-reviewed publications, nine invited talks, four MS theses, and three PhD dissertations. In this period, the PI graduated three PhD students (who also completed MS theses) and four MS students, and mentored one high-school student, three postdocs, and 14 undergraduate students, including students from local tribal colleges and other primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs) (see below).

The scientific components of this project were integrated with the PI’s long-time commitment to engage two groups of students geographically unique to the state of South Dakota and neighboring region, namely, tribal college students and students from PUIs. The outreach program focused on hosting tribal student-instructor research teams in the PI's laboratory and conducting chemistry workshops at local tribal colleges. The outreach also included onsite hosting of students from local PUIs and "at-home" support for student-faculty research teams at their home institutions. Throughout this project, the PI hosted three tribal students and one tribal faculty member to conduct MOSC-related research. The PI also organized or co-organized three on-site chemistry workshops at local tribal colleges, reaching out to ~ 45 tribal students and instructors. During this project period, the PI’s laboratory hosted six PUI students, who participated in a 10-week program working on MOSC-related research. In addition, the PI collaborated with PUI faculty on a continuous basis even after the student’s return to their home campus, maximizing the impacts of these outreach activities.


Last Modified: 06/11/2024
Modified by: Zhenqiang Wang
por.por_txt_cntn:
Catalysis is a process in which a small amount of a substance (a catalyst) accelerates the rate of desirable chemical reactions. Catalysis plays a vital role in many industrial applications. Manufacturing valuable products such as pharmaceuticals, plastics, agrochemicals, and clean fuels often requires properly designed catalysts. Traditional catalysts were highly effective in promoting a wide range of chemical reactions. However, it remained a daunting task to make catalysts that emulated the remarkable performance of enzymes, which are Nature's catalysts. The challenge arose largely from the difficulty of constructing catalyst structures that resembled the complexity of enzymes.


The overarching goal of this project was to utilize a new class of synthetic receptors, known as metal-organic supercontainers (MOSCs), to investigate new concepts of catalysis and emulate enzymatic catalysis. The unique structural characteristics of the MOSCs included their compositional versatility, structural modularity, and multi-pore architecture, which distinguished them from other types of catalysts. We established two key strategies of catalysis, namely, supramolecular catalysis via multifunctional nano-cavities and catalytic regulation via electrostatic interactions. These strategies provided new opportunities to promote catalytic efficacy, enhance reaction selectivity, and regulate supramolecular reactivity.


Through this project, we showed that MOSC catalysts featuring novel cavity structures can be custom-designed and that cavity-dependent catalytic properties can be demonstrated through chemically fine-tuning the multi-functional nano-environment of the MOSCs. Interesting size-, shape-, regio-, and chemo-selectivity can be achieved through functionalization (e.g., fluorination) of MOSC cavity, controlling the cavity size, and/or modulating the Lewis acidity or basicity of the MOSCs. We demonstrated that the endo cavity of the MOSC catalysts contained chemically versatile metal-bound 4-H2O species, which can be made catalytically active for hydrogen-bond, Brnsted-acid, or Brnsted-base catalysis, depending on the type of reactions and substrates used. We established a conceptually unique and novel strategy to modulate supramolecular catalysis using ionic species as electrostatic regulators, which were catalytically inert on their own. We examined both cationic and anionic electrostatic regulators and found that they can inhibit some reactions but promote others through mediation by the MOSC cavities.


We demonstrated that structural defects can be rationally installed in the MOSC structure to generate partially open endo cavity and labile open metal sites, which were shown to be beneficial for encapsulating/activating substrates and enabling selective oxidation of primary alcohols to carboxylic acids. We found that the otherwise hydrophobic MOSCs can be functionalized with sulfonato (-SO3-) groups to impart the MOSCs with good water-solubility. The dichotomy of an overall water-solubility and an isolated hydrophobic nano-cavity proved uniquely suited for a new form of heterogeneous catalysis at liquid-liquid interface, which points to exciting new directions of supramolecular catalysis. Finally, we developed a library of new MOSCs that retained similar multi-pore supercontainer topologies but featured distinct chemical and structural characteristics, such as a diverse range of metal ions, organic precursors, tunable pores, positive or negative charges, open metal sites, structural flexibility, etc., providing new opportunities for future supramolecular catalytic studies.


Thus, this grant provided the PI with the support to develop a new class of supramolecular catalysts that featured novel multi-cavity structure and unique catalytic characteristics. The grant contributed directly or indirectly to eight peer-reviewed publications, nine invited talks, four MS theses, and three PhD dissertations. In this period, the PI graduated three PhD students (who also completed MS theses) and four MS students, and mentored one high-school student, three postdocs, and 14 undergraduate students, including students from local tribal colleges and other primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs) (see below).


The scientific components of this project were integrated with the PIs long-time commitment to engage two groups of students geographically unique to the state of South Dakota and neighboring region, namely, tribal college students and students from PUIs. The outreach program focused on hosting tribal student-instructor research teams in the PI's laboratory and conducting chemistry workshops at local tribal colleges. The outreach also included onsite hosting of students from local PUIs and "at-home" support for student-faculty research teams at their home institutions. Throughout this project, the PI hosted three tribal students and one tribal faculty member to conduct MOSC-related research. The PI also organized or co-organized three on-site chemistry workshops at local tribal colleges, reaching out to ~ 45 tribal students and instructors. During this project period, the PIs laboratory hosted six PUI students, who participated in a 10-week program working on MOSC-related research. In addition, the PI collaborated with PUI faculty on a continuous basis even after the students return to their home campus, maximizing the impacts of these outreach activities.
